newsitem.title: USA: Floods continue along lower Ohio River.
newsitem.headline: Floods continue along lower Ohio River.

text.p: The Ohio River fell below flood stage at Cincinnati for the first time in nine days Tuesday but to the west the bloated and debris-filled stream continued to turn parts of towns into swamps.
The highest water levels Tuesday ranged from Evansville, Ind., to Golconda, Ill., the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers office in Louisville said.

At Henderson, Ky., Police Chief Ed Brady said "to the east of here, there has been a lot of devasatation," with water at rooftop level in tiny town of Reed. He said damaged estimates ran as high as $61 million in that part of western Kentucky where hundreds have been driven from their homes.

Henderson itself, a town of nearly 26,000 across the river from Evansville, is situated on a rise and not threatened. The city escaped even the devastating flood of 1937 -- the worst on record in the valley -- and its motto is "On the Ohio but Never In It."
At Smithland, Ky., a village of 300 people near where the Cumberland River flows into the Ohio, sandbagging operations were under way around the clock.
Nearby Paducah, Ky., however, remained dry behind an earthen levy and 30 floodgates that had been put up in recent days.

"It's slowly going down," said a public information officer for the corps of engineers. "Unlike most floods it's passing very slowly. And we're really happy about the blue skies we're having right now."
The crest was expected to pass out of the 981-mile (1,579 km) long Ohio Valley Thursday at Cairo, Ill., where the river joins the Mississippi.
Several towns in southern Illinois, where six counties have been declared state disaster areas, also fought steadily rising waters Tuesday.

At Metropolis, Ill., a city park was under water and the river lapped over several blocks. Nearby Fort Massac State Park was submerged but a gambling boat at Metropolis that had been cut off was scheduled to reopen Tuesday after a new walkway was built over the water to allow customers to board.
Upstream at Cincinnati the river officially fell below flood stage at dawn Tuesday, more than 13 feet (3.96 metres) lower than at its peak last Wednesday.

That was cause for celebration on the city's riverfront where most restaurants reopened after a week of lost business. The Anderson Ferry, which crosses the Ohio River between Cincinnati and northern Kentucky, was back in business.

James Witt, head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, was scheduled to tour several areas in Indiana Tuesday. Damage estimates across the states affected by the flooding have passed $500 million.
More than 30 people have died in flash floods that hit tributaries of the Ohio after more than a foot of rain fell on March 1 and in the ensuing high water.
